Community Gardens: With supermarkets closed, people could band together to create community gardens in empty lots or other unused spaces. These gardens could provide a central location for individuals to grow their own fruits, vegetables, and herbs. Community members could work together to maintain the gardens, ensuring a steady supply of fresh produce. Confidence Score: 0.8

Urban Agriculture: Cities could adopt urban agriculture practices, such as rooftop gardens, vertical farming, and hydroponics. These methods could be used to grow a wide variety of crops, including leafy greens, herbs, and even staple crops like rice and wheat. Urban agriculture could provide a sustainable source of fresh produce for cities. Confidence Score: 0.9

Local Food Systems: With supermarkets closed, people could turn to local food systems for their food needs. This could involve supporting local farmers, either through direct purchases or through community-supported agriculture (CSA) programs. By buying locally grown produce, individuals could help sustain their local agricultural economy and ensure a steady supply of fresh, healthy food. Confidence Score: 0.9

Online Marketplaces: Online marketplaces could emerge as a way for farmers to sell their produce directly to consumers. These marketplaces could be platform-based, connecting farmers with customers in their area. This would allow people to purchase fresh, locally grown produce without relying on traditional supermarkets. Confidence Score: 0.8

Bartering and Trading: In the absence of supermarkets, people could turn to bartering and trading as a means of obtaining food. This could involve exchanging goods or services for food, such as offering to mow a neighbor's lawn in exchange for a basket of fresh vegetables. Bartering and trading could help people access food without relying on cash-based transactions. Confidence Score: 0.7
